thinking.disposable_income: Mount Greenwood is relatively affluent with median income of $113,328 and 57.8% of households earning over $100,000. This suggests residents have higher disposable income and can better absorb transportation costs
thinking.discretionary_consumption: With higher incomes, residents likely have significant discretionary spending. A sales tax increase would affect this spending, but impact would be moderate given the wealth levels. Average household size of 2.6 suggests family-oriented spending patterns
thinking.accessibility: 82.2% drive alone to work, only 4.2% use transit. 95.3% of households own at least one vehicle, with 58.8% owning 2+ vehicles. This indicates heavy car dependency and limited transit usage
thinking.decision_rationale: 1. Given high car dependency, prefer policies with lower driving fees and moderate transit improvements. 2. Higher income means some tax increase is acceptable if it improves overall system. 3. Current transit usage is low, so major transit investments less beneficial. 4. Prefer balanced approaches that don't overly burden drivers while still improving transit. 5. Selected policies that maintain reasonable driving costs while providing moderate system improvements through sales tax
